body: @fkiraly I'll take a look at this. It might be related to `initial_window` again, similar to https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3700

Ok, I have found the issue. 

@chillerobscuro `ConformalIntervals` works by constructing a `residuals_matrix` based on sliding window cross-validation of the training data. This means it splits the training data into further chunks while constructing the matrix.

`ConformalIntervals` accepts an `initial_window` parameter which defines the size of the initial training set for the sliding window cross-validation. By default this is set as the larger of 0.1*len(y) and 10, which is smaller than your `AutoEnsembleForecaster` `test_size`, hence the error. 

This is an imperfect default (as discussed in the above linked issue) but it is hard to cover every use case so we are planning to make better error messages to deal with this, which suggest setting your own `initial_window`.

An easy fix is to simply overwrite the default with something greater than your `AutoEnsembleForecaster` `test_size`. 

This code snippet works:

```
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.compose import AutoEnsembleForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.exp_smoothing import ExponentialSmoothing
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon

y = load_airline()
ytrain, ytest = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=24)
print(len(ytrain), len(ytest))

fh = ForecastingHorizon(ytest.index, is_relative=False)

es = ExponentialSmoothing(sp=12)
ar = ARIMA()

forecasters = [
    ("AR", ar),
    ("ES", es)
]

ae = AutoEnsembleForecaster(forecasters=forecasters, test_size=24, method='inverse-variance')

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(ae, initial_window=48)
conformal_forecaster.fit(ytrain, fh=fh)
```

Thanks @bethrice44! I was stuck looking for arguments in `.fit()` and I should have known to look in the constructor instead.

The code snippet I put above is as minimal as possible, it does work but when I try to add a tree forecaster based pipeline I'm still getting an error about insufficient window lengths. This happens both with our tree based models and external such as `xgboost`. Am I composing the pipeline in an incompatible way or is this a further error worth investigating?

Code with tree model included:
```
from sktime.forecasting.conformal import ConformalIntervals
from sktime.forecasting.compose import AutoEnsembleForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.exp_smoothing import ExponentialSmoothing
from sktime.forecasting.arima import ARIMA
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.datasets import load_airline
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
from sktime.transformations.series.detrend import Deseasonalizer, Detrender
from sktime.forecasting.trend import PolynomialTrendForecaster
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction, TransformedTargetForecaster
from sktime.regression.interval_based import TimeSeriesForestRegressor

y = load_airline()
ytrain, ytest = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=24)
print(len(ytrain), len(ytest))

fh = ForecastingHorizon(ytest.index, is_relative=False)

es = ExponentialSmoothing(sp=12)
ar = ARIMA()
regressor = TimeSeriesForestRegressor()
tree_forecaster = TransformedTargetForecaster(
    [
        ("deseasonalize", Deseasonalizer(model="multiplicative", sp=12)),
        ("detrend", Detrender(forecaster=PolynomialTrendForecaster(degree=2))),
        ("forecast", make_reduction(regressor, window_length=24, strategy="recursive"),
        ),
    ]
)

forecasters = [
    ("Tree", tree_forecaster),
    ("AR", ar),
    ("ES", es)
]

ae = AutoEnsembleForecaster(forecasters=forecasters, test_size=24, method='inverse-variance')

conformal_forecaster = ConformalIntervals(ae, initial_window=48)
conformal_forecaster.fit(ytrain, fh=fh)
```

```
--> 145     raise ValueError(
    146         "The `window_length` and `fh` are incompatible with the length of `y`"
    147     )

    150 effective_window_length = window_length + fh_max

ValueError: The `window_length` and `fh` are incompatible with the length of `y`
```

@chillerobscuro This is a tricky one but I think its due to `make_reduction` with `ConformalIntervals` when it is constructing the `residuals_matrix`. The `window_length` in `make_reduction` has to obey `window_length + max(fh) < len(y)`. 

When the `residuals_matrix` is being constructed its using a subset of `y_train`, where the smallest subset = the size of `initial_window`. With `initial_window = 48` this `= window_length + max(fh)`, so doesn't obey the `make_reduction` check where it needs to be more. So increase `initial_window` and it should work!
Thanks @bethrice44 that seems to be the trick! Thanks for all your help.

issue.title: [ENH] principled way to deal with min-length requirements or implications of forecasters, e.g., checks or tags?

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We had a couple of cases where users reported unclear errors, coming from composites that broke due to a composite not satisfying implicit minimum length requirements (in data) of a component, e.g.:

https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3889
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3700

I think we should take some space to think about whether there is a principled solution to this issue?

A "naive complete" solution would be:

* min length tag - this may depend on parameters, so may need to be set dynamically at the end of constructor, like other tags
* "implied min length for components" tag, only for composites - can also depend on parameters

If the two are incompatible, informative error messages are raised.

The problem with this approach is that the implied min length tag can depend on parameters in quite a complex way, e.g., if a cross-validation constructor is also a parameter. In a case where there are many components (pipeline) it is possibly too complex to track even.

A "naive incomplete" solution would be: min lenght tag only, but informative error is raised with the name of the component. That would at least allow the user a guess at what is happening where.
